block.p: INTERNATIONAL

China Aid to Pakistan Complicates Vote on Trade American intelligence agencies say that China has continued to aid Pakistan's effort to build long-range missiles that could carry nuclear weapons, according to officials. The revelations are complicating President Clinton's effort to win quick Senate passage of a bill establishing normal trade relations for China.

10 of 13 Iran Jews Convicted A judge in Iran convicted 10 of 13 Jewish men accused by the Revolutionary Court of spying for Israel. Their sentences, ranging from 4 to 13 years, were seen by diplomats as harsh, drew immediate condemnation from Jewish groups and foreign governments.

Pivotal Vote in Mexico Mexican voters will choose today either to bring down the curtain on a dynasty that has governed since the Mexican revolution, or, in an outcome that would be almost as extraordinary, to inaugurate a new century by freely electing the party.

Border Dispute in Lebanon The quick deployment of United Nations peacekeepers and Lebanese forces into the stretch of southern Lebanon that Israel abandoned after 22 years of occupation has been thrown into doubt by a series of apparent Israeli incursions over a border line drawn in 1923.

Pastrana's Standing Falls President Andres Pastrana of Colombia, having just received a vote of confidence from the United States in the form of $1.3 billion in military aid, is sinking in popularity, and even his supporters fear that his standing will continue to deteriorate.
NATIONAL

Nation's Economic Boom Bypasses Plains Towns New ghost towns are sprouting over much of the Great Plains, in areas that have been bypassed by the nation's long run of prosperity. The contraction is most pronounced in North Dakota, one of only three states to lose population in the 90's.
All But Married in Vermont Vermont's new law creating marriagelike civil unions for gays took effect, and a scattering of couples rushed to take advantage of it right away.
Vote Against Same-Sex Unions The policy-making body of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) has approved a church amendment forbidding ministers from conducting same-sex unions.

The Rev. Syngman Rhee is the new moderator of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), the highest office in the nation's largest Presbyterian denomination. He is the first Asian-American to hold the job in the 211 years it has existed.
Confederate Flag Comes Down The Confederate flag atop the South Carolina Statehouse was lowered before a crowd of about 3,000 people, some relieved, some angry.

Telecoms in the Spotlight Telecommunications companies see the political conventions as high-tech trade shows, donating millions of dollars and showcasing their wares, like cell phones and high-speed Internet and telephone lines.
Perot and the Reform Party Ross Perot has told the Reform Party that he will not run for president, and he doesn't want anyone else in the party to run either.
NEW YORK/REGION

A New Intellectual Community Seeks to Establish Public Face In an effort to create an intellectual community, 15 fellows were thrown together in the Humanities and Social Sciences Library in Manhattan. Now, the Center for Scholars and Writers tries to find a public face.
Seeking Bright Professionals Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy hopes to persuade dozens of New Yorkers to quit their jobs and teach in New York City's most troubled schools this fall.
A Jefferson Mystery Two amateur historians claimed to have found the grave of a descendant of Thomas Jefferson in a cemetery in Orange County, New York, but experts were skeptical.

Jobs of Teachers of Deaf Saved The New York City teachers' union thwarted a plan by the principal of the School for the Deaf to replace teachers who are not proficient in American Sign Language with those who are, officials said.
